statement:
Let $E$ be an open subset of $\mathbb{R}^2$ and a continuous function
$f(x,y)$ defined as $f\colon E \to \mathbb{R}$. If $(x_0,y_0)\in E$ and
$f$ satisfies the Lipschitz condition in the variable $y$ in $E$:
$$|f(x,y)-f(x,y_1)| \leq M| y-y_1|$$ where $M$ is a constant. Then the
ordinary differential equation defined as $$\frac{dy}{dx} = f(x,y)$$
with the initial condition $$y(x_0) = y_0$$ has a unique solution $y(x)$
on some interval $|x- x_0| \leq\delta$.

The above theorem is also named the *Picard-Lindelöf theorem* and can be
generalized to a system of first order ordinary differential equations

Let $E$ be an open subset of $\mathbb{R}^{n+1}$ and a continuous
function $f(x,y_1,\ldots,y_n)$ defined as
$f=(f_1,\ldots,f_n)\colon E \to \mathbb{R}^n$. If
$(t_0,y_{10},\ldots,y_{n0})\in E$ and $f$ satisfies the Lipschitz
condition in the variable $y_1,\ldots,y_n$ in $E$:
$$|f_i(x,y_1,\dots,y_n)-f_i(x,y_1'\ldots,y_n')| \leq M \max_{1\leq j\leq n}| y_j-y_j'|$$
where $M$ is a constant. Then the system of ordinary differential
equation defined as $$\begin{aligned}
\frac{dy_1}{dx} & =  f_1(x,y_1,\ldots,y_n)\\
& \vdots \\
\frac{dy_n}{dx} & =  f_n(x,y_1,\ldots,y_n)\end{aligned}$$ with the
initial condition $$y_1(x_0) = y_{10},\ldots, y_n(x_0) = y_{n0}$$ has a
unique solution $$y_1(x) ,\ldots, y_n(x)$$ on some interval
$|x- x_0| \leq\delta$.

**see also:**

-   the entry existence and uniqueness of solution of ordinary
    differential equations
